4427923/4358006/4454118.title: Leigheasanna - Leicneach
4427923/4358006/4454118.text:
Ma bhíonn leicneach ort téigh isteach i gcró na muc agus abair leis an mhuic istigh "A phigín na muc tóg an leicneach uaim" Ma abaireann tú é sin trí h-uaire i ndiaidh a chéile béidh tú go maith ar an mailís.Beir an duine tinn go cumar trí n-uisge agus cuir srian asail air agus téigheadh sé treasna na g-aibhne trí h-uaire in dhíaidh a chéile agus imtheochaidh an leicneach ansinn.Déan fataí a nóstadh agus bris isteach i stoca iad abus annsin cuir leis an mball iad agus tiocfaidh faoiseamh ar ball.Deantar an rud ceadhna le salann, le bran, le builín, agus tá an cumhacht céadhna acu. Fáigh plannda sicín agus déan e do theiteadh
(continues on next page)

4428250/4388305/4456142.title: Cure of Mumps
4428250/4388305/4456142.text:
If a child in the district gets the mumps Maggie Bonnelly makes the cure. She has the cure because her mother’s maiden name was Connelly. She puts a pair of winkers [?] over the head of the patient and leads her (or him) to a spring well. Three times she dips a porringer [?] in the well and each time gives it to the patient who drinks the water and says three times “in the name of the father and of the son and of the holy ghost”.



1. The seventh son cures a toothache by rubbing it with his hand. 2. One never gets a toothache if one makes a promise (such as not shaving on a Sunday) and never breaks it.



1. Pass a wedding ring round it three times “in the name of the father and
(continues on next page)

4428221/4386925/4456913.title: Old Cures - A Cure for Chilblains
4428221/4386925/4456913.text:
A cure for chilblains. Rub a red hot knitting across (across) the chilblain.Forge water is another cure for chilblains.



In the olden times it was believed that a person suffering from mumps was cured if he was led in and out of the stable three times with the horses halter or bridle.

4428251/4388440/4465610.title: (no title)
4428251/4388440/4465610.text:
There is a disease amongst cattle known as elf-shot. The symptoms are loss of milk, and feeling very cold. In olden times it was believed the fairies did it.  There are numerous cures, such as a blessed candle. The cow is measured from the end of her tail to her nose, and the sign of the Cross, with the candle is made over her and under her for three days. Another cure is a briar with the ends growing into the ground, and the cure is made the same way. It is always successful.



There was a disease known as mumps. It was a swelling in the throat and jaws and was very painful. The old people had a very peculiar cure for it.  They put a donkey’s halter round the head of the patient and led him to a spring well where they said some prayers. This was done once a day for
(continues on next page)
4428251/4388440/4465610.school_info: School: St Joseph's, Béal Átha Seanaigh

4428251/4388443/4465627.title: (no title)
4428251/4388443/4465627.text:
The old people around Bundoran have many old cures. This is one of them. If two people of the same name marry their children have a cure for the mumps. The person getting cured is led by a halter to the nearest south-running streams, and made to drink three egg-cups full of the water.



There lived in Bonahill a man who was very fond of hunting. One day as he was out hunting he saw a hare. He put the dog on him. The dog chased him until he came to a hedge. The hare stopped here and so did the dog. The man thinking the dog had caught the hare ran
(continues on next page)
4428251/4388443/4465627.school_info: School: St Joseph's, Béal Átha Seanaigh

4428251/4388453/4465755.title: (no title)
4428251/4388453/4465755.text:
(continued from previous page)
named Kathleen was crossing the falls on horseback. As she was in the centre of the river it rose and she was drowned. Ever since they are called the “Kathleen Falls”.



Long ago people did not believe in doctors or vets. They used cures of their own. The man or woman who had the cure of the mumps, his or her father and mother had to be of the same name. The curer would take the invalid and put a halter on him and bring him to a running stream, and make the Sign of the Cross three times with the running water and in three days he was cured.
4428251/4388453/4465755.school_info: School: St Joseph's, Béal Átha Seanaigh

4428251/4388459/4465785.title: (no title)
4428251/4388459/4465785.text:
The people of Ireland have many old customs. One of them is this. At Easter the people used go out the country looking for eggs. The young people would go to every house and ask for an egg or two. They would get some eggs in every house.



Leading a child to a running stream with a donkey's halter is said to be a cure for mumps. Giving a child the milk that a ferret leaves after it, is a cure for whooping-cough. Oatmeal in an egg-stand put to the chest and some prayers said, is a cure for worms in children. When a husband and wife are both the same name before marriage, they have a cure for a disease called “rose” ? by giving the patient something to eat. It is said that there is a cure for warts. If you want to cure a
(continues on next page)
4428251/4388459/4465785.school_info: School: St Joseph's, Béal Átha Seanaigh

4427999/4366198/4468865.title: Leigheasanna - Triuch
4427999/4366198/4468865.text:
(continued from previous page)
Má fheiceann tú fear agus é ag marcaidheacht ar capall bán agus má iarrann tú air cén leigheas atá aige ar an triuch agus má dhéanann tú sin imteocaidh sé.Bhiodh leigheas eile acha freisin d'oalfadh siad mil agus d'imthigheadh an triuch annsin. Rud eile gharradh siad tuirnipí suas i bpíosaí beaga agus cuirtí siucra orra agus tiocfadh mil amach asta agus d'oalfadh siad é agus d'imthigheadh an triuch annsin.Geibhtí croiceann bruich agus bruithtí é i mbainne agus thiubharfadh siad an bainne le n-ol do'n ná daoine a mbiod an triuch orra.



Nuair a bhiodh leicneach ar dhuine fado cuirtí salainn isteach i stoca agus ceangailtí thart ar mhuineal an té a bhiodh an leicneach air d'imthigheadh an leicneach annsin. Fado nuair a bhiodh leicneach ar dhuine geibtí neantogaí agus bruithtí iad agus an t-uisge a beadh fagtaí oltaí é agus d'imthigheadh an leicneach.

4428253/4388977/4476465.title: Cure for Mumps
4428253/4388977/4476465.text:
Every son and daughter has the cure for the mumps if they have a father and mother of the one name: I you get this person to lead you by a rope to water you will soon be cured.



There is a man named Johnson who has a cure for Itch. He lives near Donegal town.



There is a cure for chin cough by going under a donkey three times.



There is a cure for warts by getting a hole in a stone in which there is water a rub it on the wart but you must not be looking for it.



There is a well in the townland of Carrickboy in which there is a cure for a headache.

4428253/4388579/4476601.title: Cures - Mumps
4428253/4388579/4476601.text: Mumps: When the father and mother of any person bear the same name that person has the cure of the mumps.Mr. P. McQuaid, West Port, Ballyshannon, has the cure of the mumps.Cut: Put (cowb) cobwebs on the cut.Scald, Red flannell is first burned to ashes. Then the ashes are put on the scald.Ericiples: Certain herbs are cut up into small pieces. Then the curer goes out and begs butter. The herbs and the butter and then minxed up and eaten by the sick person.The possesser of the cure makes a gift of it to the person who is next to receive it by imparting the names of the herbs to him or her.

4428253/4388585/4476619.title: Cure for Warts
4428253/4388585/4476619.text:
When you go into a butchers shop steal a little bit of meat and make sure there is nobody about. Bury this bit of meat and as the meat rots away the wart withers away.



A person suffering from the mumps is brought to a running stream and the person must be blindfolded. The person is then given a spoonful of water and made walk over the stream three times. This is said to cure the mumps.

4428253/4388587/4476621.title: Cure for the Mumps
4428253/4388587/4476621.text:
In olden time it was a custom to pass a person under and over a donkey three times. This is a cure for the mumps.



A sweat house was a little house under the ground in which a huge fire was lit. People suffering from influenza were put into these houses. They were rolled in blankets and stayed there until the cold was sweated out of them.

4428258/4389346/4476904.title: Local Cures - For Mumps
4428258/4389346/4476904.text:
The old people believed, that to make a cake of out bread and to give it to the donkey to eat and the crumbs that fell from from the donkey’s mouth to be given to the person suffering from mumps would cure him. A man and woman who were of the same name previous to their marriage were supposed to have the “Cure of the Mumps” The patient was taken to their house. A donkey’s halter was put on him; he was led to a spring well round which he travelled three rivers, each time taking three seefs [?] of the water Saying “In the name of the Father Son + Holy Ghost.” This custom still prevails in this school district and many of the pupils now attending have undergone the same treatment.



Whooping Cough or as it is locally known as Chin Cough. The sick child goes three times under a donkey’s (legs) each time taking a sip of the donkey’s milk saying In the name of the Father Son Holy Ghost. Two of the present day pupils at the school have had the pleasure of doing it. Their names are Margh. J Galleuogh (age 12.) and John J. McGarrigle (age12)

4428281/4391554/4479118.title: Old Cures - Mumps
4428281/4391554/4479118.text: MumpsGet a man or a woman whose father and mother were of the same name to put a pair of donkeys winkers on you and lead you to a river.Then make The Sign of the Cross on your forehead and drink three sips of the water and say “In the Name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost.
4428281/4391554/4479118.school_info: School: Scoil na gCeithre Máighistrí, Dún na nGall

4428291/4392225/4479392.title: A Cure for Mumps
4428291/4392225/4479392.text: A donkey’s halter should be put on the person who has the mumps. Then he should be driven to the river and back seven times. Each time the person must take a drink of water which he has to keep in his mouth until he returns. Then he foes over on his head three times, spits out the water & pulls three hairs out of his head.

4481725/4408554/4481776.title: A Cure for the Mumps
4481725/4408554/4481776.text: A well known cure for the mumps and one much used in Donegal is for the person suffering from the mumps to put on a horses winkers and then proceed to a stream or well. Arrived at the stream or well he was supposed to drink from it if he wished to get cured.

4493627/4405062/4514513.title: St Brigid's Eve Custom
4493627/4405062/4514513.text:
On St. Brigids Eve the Donegal people make crosses of rushes and "poundies" for supper. After supper the oldest member of the family goes out for rushes. When he comes back he knocks at the door and says "Fosgail an doras agus leig isteac Brigid." Some one inside answers "Se do beatha a Brighid" three times. then the rushes are made into crosses. On Candlemass day holy water is thrown on them. They are then hung up in every room in the house and every out houses well. The crosses are shaped thus [sketch of cross]



When a person has mumps a donkey's halter is put on his head.Then a husband & wife who were of the same surname before marriage lead him round a well three times.Then he was cured.

4428404/4404934/4514991.title: A Local Cure for Mumps
4428404/4404934/4514991.text: In this locality the people believe in a simple cure for Mumps. A person puts a horses halter on the one that is sick and leads him to a stream. Here the man or woman who leads the sick person throws some water on him and he soon recovers. The parents of the one who cures had the same surname before marriage.Next door to my home in the townland of Carrowtrasna in the Parish of Gartan there is a lady named Mrs Mary Doohan who cures Mumps in this way. My sister Florrie was cured by her.

4493685/4410547/4524635.title: Leigheasanna - Déideadh
4493685/4410547/4524635.text:
Fagh frog óg agus cuir a cheann í do bhéul agus deán trí chagnamh uirtí in Ainm an Athair agus an mhic agus an spiorad naomh. Ansín imtheochaidh an deideadh.



Ma tá plucamas ar d uine  cuir air cuidh de ughaim asail agus tabháir gó dtí an tobair é.Innis do  deoch a slugad o n tobáir agus geobháid sé biseach ón am sin.

4493706/4412842/4528507.title: Folk Cures and Charms - Stye on the Eye
4493706/4412842/4528507.text:
Nine gooseberry thorns were gathered. The patient then gave his stye a prick with each of the nine, and when finished with the ninth he threw it over his right shoulder. Then he commenced again with right and threw the eighth over his right shoulder when finished with it. Likewise with the seven remaining, then six, five [?] until the last one has been thrown away.



Any person, male or female, both whose parents had the same surname before marriage was supposed to be able to cure mumps. The ceremony was as follows:-The sick person was "led" - that is, a halter was put over his head and he was taken thus, before sunset to a burn which had to be on the 'march'
(continues on next page)

4493747/4416474/4529805.title: How to Cure Mumps
4493747/4416474/4529805.text:
When children had mumps long ago their father or their mother put horse's winkers on the one that had the mumps, and led them to the well and let them take three drinks of water and after that they got better.



First the people get a donkey and made it eat oat bread. There were two people, one stood at each side of the donkey then they reached through the one that had whooping cough three times over the donkey's back and through its four legs: after that the child got better.

4547213/4414030/4547851.title: Cures - The Cure for Mumps
4547213/4414030/4547851.text:
When a man and woman bearing the same name marry, every child of that couple can cure mumps. This Rose Boland's grannie is Mrs Rose Doherty of Meenglass. Mrs Dohertys maiden name was Rose Tonner, and both of her parents were Tonner i.e. Rose Boland's great grandmother's maiden name was Tonner even before she married her husband John Tonner. On that account Rose Boland's grannie cures mumps. The curer puts a halter on the sick persons head and then leads him across a burn ( a steam) separating two town lands and then leads him back. This is done once a day for three days in succession. The curer prays - Mrs Doherty is now very still but she cures people still. Instead of leading the patient she holds on to the reins and the person walks over and back alone.



Anybody who wishes can cure heart fever. The curer gets a silk ribbon and a long piece of flaxen thread or sewing. The thread is double and runs up front and down back of ribbon. The curer then rolls up the ribbon with thread, into a tight roll and blesses himself.
(continues on next page)

4602731/4599394/4631959.title: Mumps
4602731/4599394/4631959.text: A person who has a father and mother of the same name puts a halter on the person suffering from the mumps and brings her to a river. The person having the mumps take a drink out of the water and says "In the name of the Father." (and of the Son and) then she goes away and comes back again and takes another drop and says "And of the Son." She goes away a third time comes back again takes another drop and says "And of the Holy Ghost. Amen."

4602731/4599395/4631960.title: Mumps
4602731/4599395/4631960.text: People had an opinion that the seventh son or daughter who had a father and a mother of the same name had the cure for the mumps. That person, boy or girl, would bring a female donkey to a stream and the person having the mumps would be put in under the donkey and out over his back three times. The person having the mumps had to take a drink from the stream each time and while this was going on the donkey was kept eating out meal bread.

4602746/4600488/4632635.title: The Cure of the Mumps
4602746/4600488/4632635.text: In the townland of Glenboy a man named Dan Mc Morrow who had the cure of the mumps. The way he makes the cure is he puts a halter on the person and leads them to a well and gives them three sips of water and while doing that he says some prayers.ByMolly Mac Morrow.

4602736/4599744/4633299.title: The Cure of the Mumps
4602736/4599744/4633299.text: Some people have the cure of the mumps. A person whose father's name and mother's maiden name are the same has the cure of the mumps. For instance Mr Lawrence McGowan of Drummonds Gurteen P.O., Manorhamilton has this cure. This man is living in Glencar. The mumps are taken in the throat. If the mumps are not cured the person that has them would be choked. Mr Lawrence McGowan puts the mare's halter on the patient's throat and leads them to the three mearing water. Just where the water meets he stoops down and lifts up a drop of water in his hand. He gives them three drops to drink. He takes off the halter and the sick person goes home.

4605937/4603900/4644083.title: The Cure of the Mumps
4605937/4603900/4644083.text: The father and mother must be the one name before a person has the cure of the mumps. The cure is to be found at Mrs. Crowne's where three townlands meet. The cure is made by the person who has the cure and the person who has the mumps must be led to the three mearing water and get three drops of the water in the name of the father Son and holy Ghost. Thus must be given for three days and then the cure is made. The person must be led to the three mearing water once every day for three days and then the cure is made.

4613718/4612162/4644755.title: Old Cures - Mumps
4613718/4612162/4644755.text: Children having Mumps were cured by a father and mother who were born of the same surname.If the cure was no good they put a [?] on the child and drove him to a South running stream, where he had to drink three sips of the water.

4649689/4647439/4650773.title: A Cure for Mumps
4649689/4647439/4650773.text: 5A Cure For MumpsI heard my father, John Doherty, Letterfine, Keshcarrigan say that he had the cure of the mumps.  He said that it is commonly believed in our locality that any persons whose father and mother are of the same name before marriage have that cure.  He also told me that his father and mother were of the same name before they were married.  He said that this cure is performed by swinging the person who has the mumps over a drain each time "in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost."  The drain must be running from three townlands, and the person must have his head in an asses  bridle.  He said that his is believed to cure the disease.  He said he has that cure.James, Thomas, Doherty.

4649698/4648291/4658938.title: Cures - Mumps
4649698/4648291/4658938.text:
Put an asses straddle and mats on the person having the mumps, let them go around the PigSty three times on their hands and feet - and each time sayBig Pig [cugat?] the mumps.



a) Do a station at St Brigids Well, Ballinamore.b) Rub a stone off a grave to the jaw.c) Rub the aching jaw with a stone off a priest's grave.

4658439/4655791/4659961.title: The Cure of the Mumps
4658439/4655791/4659961.text:
Mumps is a common disease. There is one cure that puts it away. A bridle is got and put on the head of the person who has the disease and he goes around the stable three times and each time he goes around he has to put in his head each time on the door of the stable. And it will go away in a day or two after.



When people sprain any part of them they get the cure of the sprain made And this is the way to make it. As Our Lord was crossing over the Alps, he sprained his asses' foot, He alighted and said "blood to blood and bone to bone and every sinew in its own place" To make the cure you pick nine dandelions, then say one Our Father and three Hail Mary's
(continues on next page)

4658454/4657267/4662267.title: Local Cures - Mumps
4658454/4657267/4662267.text:
Mumps. Meet a man riding a white horse accidentally. Ask him for a cure and do whatever he tells you.James O'Rourke(86)



Put an asses' head stall on the person afflicted. Lead him around the pig sty three times saying " Pig O the mumps" while doing it J. O'Rourke(86)



To take out thorn- Chew leaf put it on a piece of cloth lie arounf thorn.John Maxwell, Carrickmakeegan.



Corn: Melt pieces of candle, melt it and pour parafin over it and put it on the corn. J. Maxwell



Get a leaf of slánlus and boil it in a cup of water mix with butter and place it on cut.



To Draw Boils: Roast Slánlus leaf and apply- one side (the smooth) draws, the other side heals.

4658454/4657267/4662269.title: Local Cures - Mumps
4658454/4657267/4662269.text:
Mumps. Meet a man riding a white horse accidentally. Ask him for a cure and do whatever he tells you.James O'Rourke(86)



Put an asses' head stall on the person afflicted. Lead him around the pig sty three times saying " Pig O the mumps" while doing it J. O'Rourke(86)



To take out thorn- Chew leaf put it on a piece of cloth lie arounf thorn.John Maxwell, Carrickmakeegan.



Corn: Melt pieces of candle, melt it and pour parafin over it and put it on the corn. J. Maxwell



Get a leaf of slánlus and boil it in a cup of water mix with butter and place it on cut.



To Draw Boils: Roast Slánlus leaf and apply- one side (the smooth) draws, the other side heals.

4701665/4691093/4707841.title: The Cure of the Mumps
4701665/4691093/4707841.text: The Cure of the Mumps   20-12.38Long ago when a person had the mumps he usually got the cure made by some person who had the cure.  The person who has the cure of the mumps is the older member of a family whose parents had the same surnames.The way in which the person makes the cure is he would come to the house where the child who had the mumps lived.  He would bring with him a donkey's winkers and a piece of home made unsalted butter.  Then he would put the donkey's winkers on the sick child and lead the child to a stream where three mearing water's meet.  The chid would take three mouthfuls of the water then the curer would lead the child home again.  Then the person  would put some of the butter on the neck of the child and he would leave some of it on a stone for the good people which was a custom long ago.  this would be done for three days and on the third day the mumps would be all gone.Told by Mrs Jane McGloinWritten in by Bridget Gilmartin (age 14 years)

4701657/4690240/4725379.title: The Cure of the Mumps
4701657/4690240/4725379.text:
Years ago when a person was suffering from the "Mumps" somebody got an ass's halter and led the sick person to a three mearing water. Then the sick person drank three drinks of this water saying while doing so "In the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost, Amen" three times, namely one time for each drink.Within a day's time the sick person was completely cured.



A man named Francis Healy who lives in the townland of Crearyheel, Parish of Ahamlish,
(continues on next page)

4701685/4692573/4728172.title: Local Cures - Headache
4701685/4692573/4728172.text:
(a) Measure the head with a tape, and say some prayers.(b) Say three "Hail Marys" on your Rosary-beads in the morning.(c) Put heated salt in a stocking and tie it round your neck.



Take a raw potato; run the dirt off with a damp cloth; cut it into thick slices and lay these on the forehead.



Take three pinches of sugar or salt after each other.



Dandelion heartease.



Swallow a cup of salt water very slowly.



Special roots, which only some people can find.



(a) The sufferer's cousin should drive him to three "mairn[?]" waters with an asse's halter round his neck; and drink of the three waters.(b) Put a horse's bridle on the sufferer's head and bring the patient to a spring well three times.(c) Put the patients neck in an ass's halter and walk him in and
(continues on next page)
4701685/4692573/4728172.school_info: School: Scoil na mBráthar Sligeach (Sráid na Céibhe)

4701691/4693024/4743846.title: Mumps
4701691/4693024/4743846.text: Make a horse hair halter and put it round the neck of the person who is suffering from mumps, then lead him in and out the pig-sty door three times and say each time, "a mhuc, mhuc, chugat an leicneach"Heat salt and put it in a wool stocking and tie it round the neck of the person who has mumps.

4758455/4745543/4786917.title: Cure for the Mumps
4758455/4745543/4786917.text: In the months of November and December most of the school children had the mumps.One day a gentleman came into the school and told us a cure for them.  This is the cure :-Get an asses bridle and place it on the head of the affected child.  Then take the child and lead him three times around the pig-sty saying those words "Muc, muc chugat an leicneach.  In ainm an Athair agus an Mhic agus an Spiorad Naoimh, Amén."The words are to be repeated three times.  This is a proven cure for mumps.Teller of the storySergeant Mac GahernGárda StationCootehallArdcarne Parish

4742056/4731346/4815563.title: Cures - Mumps
4742056/4731346/4815563.text: Put on a horses halter and get someone to lead you across a stream three times. Make salt very hot in a pan, put the salt in a woollen stocking a tie about your neck before going to bed. Gargle with a glass full of hot water with a half teaspoonful of salt and bread soda in it.

4798708/4792151/4924725.title: Old Cures - Mumps
4798708/4792151/4924725.text: MumpsThis was a disease which was very common amongst children. There was a cure for it and people would never dream of getting a doctor. It was usually when not taken in time. It was usually detected by a swelling on both sides of the neck and under the ears particularlyThe breath was sometimes almost stopped and children were oftentimes nearly chocked. The people rubbed and poulticed the affected parts but nothing seemed to be of any use until the cure was tried.The cure consisted in putting a donkeys winkers on the head of the sufferer leading him three times around the pig sty saying at the same time some prayers. If there was no sty near a child had to be brought a long distance to where there was a detached sty . In many places in those days the pig sty was usually built at the end of dwelling house, and on that account the cure could not be tried there

4701657/4690238/4955263.title: The Cure of the Ringworm
4701657/4690238/4955263.text:
(continued from previous page)
When a person in this district is suffering from ringworm he or she goes to this woman. She says certain prayers and makes the sign of the cross three times with her finger on the sore part.Three visits are paid to Mrs McGowan. Immediately after the third visit a cure takes place.



Long ago when a person suffered from a disease called the "Mumps", some other person got an asses halter and put it on the sick person's head.Another person drove the sick person into a pig sty and all around the walls inside saying while doing so "In the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost, amen."This was repeated three times and after a few hours the person was

5008822/4959057/5071939.title: (no title)
5008822/4959057/5071939.text:
When a person has the mumps he must get the winkers of a horse and have them put on his head. Then he has to be led into a pig-sty three times in succession making the sign of the cross each time he's led in. He will then be cured.



If the hair on a boys head begins to fall he must get the marrow out of a bone and rub it on his head for nine mornings and his hair will grow again.

5044783/5037718/5083748.title: Cure for Mumps
5044783/5037718/5083748.text: Mumps - which is a swelling in the neck, mostly under the ears and round the front part underneath your chin, sometimes occasions great trouble. This can be cured at home by any person and in the following manner:-Put a halter round the neck of the afflicted one, and lead him or her, as the case may be, three times round the pig sty. This must be repeated three times also, and like all other cures on Mondays and Thursdays, after sunrise and before sunset.

5044837/5042886/5087593.title: The Cure for the Mumps
5044837/5042886/5087593.text: Another bad disease is the mumps. It is like a sore throat, and in fact, it is a swelling of the lungs. It generally goes away after a little while but in case of it lingering the ancient cure still holds good: A donkey's halter is put round the sufferer's throat and if he or she is led out to the pigsty three times, saying, while doing so, some words in Irish. That prescription to bring relief very soon.

5044833/5042588/5091439.title: Local Cures
5044833/5042588/5091439.text:
In the olden times rickets in children were cured by a black-smith. He brought the child around the anvil three times and he said a prayer. That was done once a week for three weeks. The old people long ago cured ring-worm with mustard. Another cure for ring-worm is to but a cloth into linseed oil and put it on the ring-worm.



People lead children who have mumps round a pig sty several times with a halter on them. If you had whooping cough your father or mother would ask the first man whom they met on the road with a piebald pony what would cure it and he would tell you some-thing to eat or drink. When old men get their hair cut they gather it up every hair and put it in a hole on a ditch.They believe that you will have to come back some time from the next world to collect it "so they put it in a place in which it will be easily got".



Get a hairy-lone-worm - bore a hole in a tree - put the worm in the hole in the name of the Father, Son and Holy Ghost, cork the hole and the child for whom you do that will never take the C. Cough

The ass though looked upon as a stupid animal, is a born leader. All other animals recognise this, but man thinks different.

5070765/5060652/5093445.title: Local Cures - Cure for Mumps
5070765/5060652/5093445.text:
When a person has the mumps there is an old cure for it. Put the ass'es halter on the person and drive him round the pig-sty three times and say "muca, muca ye take leicne" and the pigs take the mumps and the person gets better.



Make a poultice of nettles and apply to the affected parts. Make nettle tea and give frequent drinks of it to the patient and keep him in bed.



Leave the horse out the stormiest weather in Winter and give him no oats at all, and soon the horse will be well.

5070783/5062916/5094738.title: The Cure of the Mumps
5070783/5062916/5094738.text: The cure of the mumps.In the past a child found suffering from the mumps was taken by an old woman to a pig sty with a donkeys winkers on it head and this old women who possessed the cure, would walk the affected child three times round the pig sty saying, "muc má, muc má, sin a go the leckme" and this is said to be the cure. A second cure also believed in is, the sufferer was put to creep under an ass, or as it is better known, as under the asses belly and this like the last had to be done three times.

Long ago, when people used to take the mumps in their throats, the cure in those days was:- their mother would make them get up at three o'clock in the morning and put a cloth over their eyes and walk them round the pig sty saying these words:-A mhuclach! First you get a herb which will be found growing on a mossy bank or in a meadow. The herb has green leaves and a pink flower. Sometimes it is hard to get. You wash the herb, clean it, and put it in a saucepan with about a pint of sweet milk. Put it on the fire to boil and when boiled, strain it and give it to the patient to drink. The patient has to get in three times before he gets better.

The cure for the mumps given by Mrs Egleston, nee Malone, is a queer one. Walking round a pig-sty three times you had to say the following rhyme: "Mucna, mucna, sine go na leicne. Laith se an na muicne." Since then the rhyme was changed to three Hail Marys. I am not sure of the correct spelling but it was like that, the rhyme sounded. A pot hanger was hung round the neck whilst this was being performed.



A local woman from Athlumney named Mrs Murphy has a very good cure for ringworm. She has a gold ring which is kept in a little box of holy water, and wadding wrapped around it. She rubs the ring to the person affected three times a day saying at the same time, "In the name of the father, and of the son, and of the holy ghost amen."
